title: What are the disadvantages of having a musical instrument? - Quora

response.answer_text: None. Once you begin to play your instrument, of course, it will experience wear and tear. Pianos need to be tuned ($100 or so), from once a year to three years or so, depending on humidity, usage, heat, etc. If you move a lot, the cost of a mover (or pizza for friends who have a pickup truck) needs to be considered. If you want a pipe organ, a tuba, trombone or trumpet, or drums, you’d better consider your neighbors! All acoustical instruments have moving parts or strings, but need surprisingly little lubrication or maintenance. A few bottles of oil will keep your trumpet going for two hundred years - more than a few drops can ruin a Hammond organ (by the way, that’s in instrument you can make whisper-soft, if you live in an apartment - also electronic keyboards are no only volume-adjustable, you can put all the sound through headsets and rock out and your neighbors will never know). Playing instruments is good for your health; and you can play piano keys millions of times and never hurt your hand.

I don’t know that there are any disadvantages to owning any musical instrument. There are challenges, most certainly. For example, every saxophone will need to be re-padded by a competent instrument repair technician at several times during its life. In addition, the string bass: I’ve never seen anyone transport one of these in a Mini Cooper. I recommend finding Garrison Keillor’s The Young Lutheran’s Guide to the Orchestra. It’s a parody of Britten’s The Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra. Keillor goes through a tongue-in-cheek analysis of each instrument family in the orchestra, with an emphasis on how it does or does not promote Christian values. It’s hilarious! And sort of on point. :)
